image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: Pakistan arming JF-17 jets with Ra'ad nuke missiles
item.description: A recent image from the 2023 Pakistan Day Parade rehearsals revealed a JF-17 Thunder Block II aircraft carrying a Ra'ad-I air-launched cruise missile, marking its first public observation. This indicates Pakistan's progress in equipping JF-17s for nuclear capabilities, potentially replacing the ageing Mirage III/Vs. The development occurs amid regional nuclear arms competition and heightened tensions between Pakistan, India, and China.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: Taiwan says China seizes fishing boat near its coast
item.description: China views democratically governed Taiwan as its own territory and has ramped up pressure on Taipei since May when President Lai Ching-te took office, a man Beijing accuses of being a "separatist".

item.title: China leading generative AI patents race, UN report says
Russia's largest Black Sea Port under drone attack, beaches closed for safety
item.description: The mayor of Novorossiysk announced restricted beach access due to a sea drone attack repelled by Russian defence forces. Two sea drones were destroyed near the crucial Black Sea port, a key oil export hub. The Russian defence ministry also reported downing 10 Ukrainian drones. Kyiv claims these attacks are retaliation for Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine since 2022.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: UK election: Sunak battles to the end as Labour's Starmer eyes victory

item.title: Man accused of stabbing Salman Rushdie rejects plea deal, faces longer jail time

item.title: Japan's Supreme Court to deliver verdict on forced sterilizations under eugenics law
item.description: Japan’s Supreme Court will rule Wednesday on the defunct eugenics law that led to the forced sterilization of around 16,500 people. Victims seek compensation and an apology for decades of suffering. The law, in effect from 1948 to 1996, permitted sterilisations to prevent "poor quality descendants." The ruling could impact ongoing and future claims against the government.
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: How trash-carrying balloons from North Korea have led to major flight disruptions in South Korea
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'China can end Russia’s war in Ukraine with one phone call'
item.description: Finnish President Alexander Stubb said that Russia's dependence on China has reached a level where Beijing could potentially end the war in Ukraine. In a Helsinki interview, Stubb emphasized that a single phone call from Chinese President Xi Jinping could resolve the crisis. Stubb's remarks highlight the growing frustration among Ukraine's allies regarding China's perceived support for Russia, which includes providing technologies, weapon parts, and aiding in circumventing trade restrictions.

item.title: Who is Rishi Shah? The Indian-American ex-billionaire who frauded Google, Goldman
item.dc:creator: TOI News Desk

item.title: Young man's death goes unnoticed for 30 hours in China internet cafe
item.description: A man was found dead at an internet cafe after staff mistook him for sleeping. He passed away during a gaming session, unnoticed for 30 hours. Concerns were raised over lack of monitoring, and local police are investigating. The incident highlights fears over sudden deaths in China.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: US Supreme Court rejects teen sex abuse victim's bid to revive Snapchat lawsuit
What is the new OSHA rule? Biden proposes heat protection regulations as US swelters
item.description: The proposed OSHA heat rules, supported by President Joe Biden, aim to safeguard workers from extreme temperatures. California faces wildfires and record heat, with health experts stressing the importance of heat stroke awareness. The proposal faces potential opposition from businesses and trade groups, highlighting the ongoing challenges posed by climate change.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Ram Mandir replica to debut at New York's India Day parade
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Hurricane Beryl kills seven as it churns towards Jamaica
item.description: Hurricane Beryl churned towards Jamaica Tuesday, with forecasters warning of potentially deadly winds and storm surge, after the storm killed at least seven people and caused widespread destruction across the southeastern Caribbean. As of 2300 GMT, Beryl had maximum sustained winds of 150 miles (240 kilometers) per hour as it headed towards Jamaica and the Cayman Islands on Tuesday, according to the NHC. A hurricane watch and tropical storm warnings have also been issued for parts of Haiti.

item.title: Astronaut who clicked iconic 'Earthrise' photo died while doing Flyby
item.description: According to the NTSB report, Anders had informed his friend via text message about his intention to conduct a flyby near her residence on the western shore of Orcas Island. The friend stated that such flybys were not uncommon for Anders, who typically performed two passes and occasionally rocked the airplane's wings but "he never performed any kind of aerobatic maneuvers.”
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Chinese firms eye Morocco as way to cash in on US electric vehicle subsidies
Rage, sadness, frustration: Turmoil in the White House over Joe Biden
item.description: US President Joe Biden on Tuesday acknowledged his performance during last Thursday's presidential debate wasn't his best, but blamed it on jet lag after two overseas trips earlier in June. Biden has faced mounting questions about his 2024 reelection bid after last week's shaky debate performance, with one House of Representatives fellow Democrat on Tuesday publicly calling on him to withdraw from the race. Speaking at a campaign event in McLean, Virginia, on Tuesday evening, Biden admitted the debate against former President Donald Trump, his Republican rival, did not go well.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: China seizes Taiwanese fishing boat, warns Taiwan not to interfere
item.description: Tensions rise as Chinese maritime enforcement persists near Kinmen following the deaths of two Chinese fishermen. President Lai Ching-te's term sees increased pressure from China, prompting Taiwan to seek communication for detained fishermen's release.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk
